text: Forever associated with Charles is Archbishop Laud, now so much nobler a figure than former historians led us to believe. Laud was enthusiastically hated by Calvinists and Puritans, and the sentiment was mutual. But Laud was no Romanizer. One of his first public acts was a hard-hitting battle with the Jesuit, Fisher. But anyone who was friendly with James and Charles, the Puritans argued, was necessarily a menace.
handwritten_text: Forever associated with Charles is Archbishop Laud, now so much nobler a figure than former historians led us to believe. Laud was enthusiastically hated by Calvinists and Puritans, and the sentiment was mutual. But Laud was no Romanizer. One of his first public acts was a hard-hitting battle with the Jesuit, Fisher. But anyone who was friendly with James and Charles, the Puritans argued, was necessarily a menace.
